14 Days

14-Day Extreme Adventure Mexico

Canyons, Caves, Cliffs & Caribbean: Mexico's Ultimate Adrenaline Journey

Mexico is an adventure playground hiding in plain sight. While most visitors stick to beaches and ruins, we're diving into cenote caves, rappelling into sinkholes, hiking North America's deepest canyon, swimming with whale sharks, and exploring underground rivers. This 14-day itinerary is for those who want their heart racing as much as their mind expanding.

Trip Highlights

  • Copper Canyon rim-to-rim hike
  • Cenote cave diving or freediving
  • Rappelling into underground cenotes
  • Whale shark swimming (seasonal)
  • Underground river exploration
  • Desert dune surfing
Duration
14 Days
Best Time
October to May for most activities; June-September for whale sharks
Budget (Mid-Range)
$5,500-8,000 USD per person

Day-by-Day Itinerary

1

Arrive Mexico City

Mexico City

Arrive in Mexico City and settle into your hotel in Roma or Condesa neighborhoods. This afternoon, get your blood pumping with a urban adventure: bike tour through Chapultepec Forest to the top of Chapultepec Castle, then explore the city's best street food by foot. Evening briefing for the adventures ahead—your guides will prep you for the coming two weeks.

Today's Activities:
  • Arrive Mexico City
  • Check into Roma/Condesa hotel
  • Bike tour through Chapultepec
  • Castle climb
  • Street food walking tour
  • Adventure briefing dinner
2

Fly to Copper Canyon

Copper Canyon

Early flight to Chihuahua, then transfer to Creel—the gateway to Copper Canyon (Barrancas del Cobre). Deeper and larger than the Grand Canyon, this is one of Earth's most dramatic landscapes. Afternoon acclimatization hike along the rim with jaw-dropping views. Meet your canyon guide and prepare for the rim-to-rim descent beginning tomorrow.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning flight to Chihuahua
  • Transfer to Creel (3 hours)
  • Lunch in Creel
  • Rim acclimatization hike
  • Canyon viewpoints
  • Gear check and briefing
  • Early dinner and rest
3

Copper Canyon Descent

Copper Canyon

The adventure begins. Depart at dawn for the descent into the Urique Canyon—the deepest of Copper Canyon's six canyons (6,136 feet deep). Today's hike takes you from pine forests at the rim through multiple climate zones to subtropical canyon floor. The trail is ancient Tarahumara routes. Camp tonight in the canyon with your guides.

Today's Activities:
  • Pre-dawn departure
  • Begin rim descent
  • Pass through climate zones
  • Trail lunch with views
  • Continue to canyon floor
  • Set up camp
  • Campfire dinner under stars
4

Canyon Floor & Tarahumara Villages

Copper Canyon

Explore the canyon floor along the Urique River. Visit a Tarahumara (Rarámuri) village—the legendary running people who call these canyons home. Optional morning swim in river pools. Afternoon ascent begins, camping midway on the return climb. Stars in the canyon are extraordinary.

Today's Activities:
  • Canyon floor exploration
  • River swimming
  • Tarahumara village visit
  • Traditional lunch
  • Begin ascent hike
  • Midway camp
  • Stargazing
5

Ascent & El Chepe Train

Copper Canyon to Divisadero

Complete the canyon ascent—legs burning, spirit soaring. Late morning, board the legendary El Chepe train at Divisadero for one of the world's most spectacular rail journeys. The train hugs canyon walls, crosses incredible trestle bridges, and offers views impossible from any road. Continue to Posada Barrancas for the night.

Today's Activities:
  • Early morning ascent completion
  • Return to rim
  • Board El Chepe train at Divisadero
  • Scenic rail journey
  • Observation car experience
  • Arrive Posada Barrancas
  • Recovery dinner
6

Fly to Oaxaca

Oaxaca

Morning flight to Oaxaca City via Chihuahua and Mexico City. Arrive early afternoon in Oaxaca—a completely different Mexico of green valleys and ancient Zapotec culture. Rest at your hotel, then evening walking tour of the zócalo, mezcal tasting at a traditional mezcalería, and incredible Oaxacan cuisine for dinner.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning departure Copper Canyon
  • Flights to Oaxaca
  • Hotel check-in
  • Rest and recovery
  • Evening walking tour
  • Mezcal tasting
  • Oaxacan dinner
7

Hierve el Agua & Monte Albán

Oaxaca

Adventure meets archaeology. Morning visit to Monte Albán—the ancient Zapotec capital atop a mountain, with challenging hiking around the pyramids. Afternoon at Hierve el Agua—petrified waterfalls with natural infinity pools overlooking the valley. Cliff jumping into the pools for the brave. Return for traditional Oaxacan dinner.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning at Monte Albán ruins
  • Climb pyramids and explore
  • Transfer to Hierve el Agua
  • Lunch en route
  • Swim in petrified pools
  • Optional cliff jumping
  • Sunset at Hierve el Agua
  • Return to Oaxaca for dinner
8

Fly to Riviera Maya

Riviera Maya

Fly from Oaxaca to Cancún, transfer to the Riviera Maya. This is where Mexican adventure reaches another level—the world's longest underwater cave systems await. Check into your hotel in Tulum or Playa del Carmen. Afternoon briefing with your cenote and diving guides. Evening exploring Tulum's bohemian beach road.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning flight to Cancún
  • Transfer to Riviera Maya
  • Hotel check-in
  • Cenote/diving briefing
  • Equipment check
  • Tulum exploration
  • Beach dinner
9

Cenote Cave Diving or Freediving

Cenotes

The main event for underwater adventurers. Certified cave divers: explore the Dos Ojos or Sac Actun systems—the world's longest underwater cave systems. Freedive certified: guided cenote freediving with depths to 30+ meters. Snorkelers: incredible cenote snorkeling in crystal waters with light beams. All groups: unforgettable subterranean exploration.

Today's Activities:
  • Early departure for cenotes
  • Cenote briefing and gear up
  • First dive/freedive/snorkel
  • Surface interval with jungle lunch
  • Second cenote exploration
  • Third cenote (divers)
  • Return to hotel
  • Casual dinner and rest
10

Cenote Rappelling & Underground Rivers

Cenotes & Underground Rivers

Different cenotes, different adventure. Morning rappelling into a cenote sinkhole—descending 100+ feet into the jungle floor to reach hidden pools. Afternoon at Río Secreto or similar—exploring underground rivers by swimming, wading, and climbing through cave systems. This is adventure you can't find anywhere else.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning transfer to rappelling cenote
  • Safety briefing and gear up
  • 100+ foot rappel descent
  • Cenote swimming and exploration
  • Ascent
  • Lunch
  • Underground river exploration
  • Swimming through caves
  • Return to hotel
11

Transfer to Holbox

Holbox Island

Travel to Holbox Island—a car-free paradise off the Yucatán coast. Ferry from Chiquilá brings you to sandy streets and Caribbean calm. This is base camp for tomorrow's whale shark adventure (seasonal) or reef diving. Afternoon kayaking through mangroves, evening bioluminescence tour—paddle through waters that glow with every stroke.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning transfer to Chiquilá
  • Ferry to Holbox
  • Check into beachfront hotel
  • Afternoon mangrove kayaking
  • Beach time and rest
  • Early dinner
  • Bioluminescence night tour
12

Whale Sharks or Reef Adventure

Holbox / Caribbean

If June-September: swim with whale sharks—the world's largest fish, up to 40 feet long. A boat ride to feeding areas, then snorkeling alongside these gentle giants. Off-season: deep reef diving at Cabo Catoche or exploration of lesser-known cenotes. Either way, an unforgettable day in the water. Evening celebration dinner on the beach.

Today's Activities:
  • Early morning departure
  • Boat ride to whale shark feeding grounds
  • Multiple swims with whale sharks
  • Lunch on boat
  • Return to Holbox
  • Rest and beach time
  • Celebration dinner
13

Return to Cancún

Cancún

Morning ferry and transfer back to Cancún area. Final afternoon for any missed adventures: parasailing, jet skiing, or simply beach relaxation. Evening farewell dinner reflecting on two weeks of extraordinary experiences—from the depths of Copper Canyon to the underwater caves of the Yucatán.

Today's Activities:
  • Morning in Holbox
  • Ferry and transfer to Cancún
  • Hotel check-in
  • Optional final adventure activity
  • Beach time
  • Farewell dinner
14

Departure

Cancún Airport

Final morning in Mexico. After 14 days of adventures spanning deserts, canyons, mountains, caves, and Caribbean waters, you've experienced a Mexico few travelers ever see. Head to the airport with incredible stories, physical fatigue in the best way, and a profound appreciation for Mexico's adventure potential.

Today's Activities:
  • Final breakfast
  • Airport transfer
  • Departure

Practical Information

Getting There

Multi-city routing: Fly into Mexico City (MEX), internal flights to Chihuahua and Oaxaca, fly out of Cancún (CUN). Book internal flights on Volaris or VivaAerobus for best prices. Alternative: Start and end in Cancún, fly to Chihuahua roundtrip.

Getting Around

Mix of internal flights, arranged transfers, and ferries. Copper Canyon requires guided transportation. Riviera Maya works well with rental car or arranged tours. Holbox is car-free.

Frequently Asked Questions

How fit do I need to be for this itinerary?

Very fit. The Copper Canyon rim-to-rim hike is strenuous (12-15 miles per day with significant elevation change). Cenote activities require strong swimming. Train for several months with hiking, swimming, and cardio before attempting this itinerary.

Can I do cenote cave diving without cave certification?

You can do cavern diving (always in natural light) with Open Water certification. Full cave diving requires Cave or Cavern certification. If you're not certified but want this experience, consider getting certified before your trip—courses are offered in Playa del Carmen.

What if I'm not there during whale shark season?

October-May offers different adventures: bull shark diving (November-March), sea turtle nesting (May-October), or incredible reef diving year-round. Holbox is worth visiting any time for its pristine beauty and bioluminescence.

Is this trip safe?

With proper guides and operators, yes. Every adventure activity uses certified guides and proper safety equipment. The Yucatán and Copper Canyon are safe regions for tourists. Travel insurance with adventure activity coverage is essential.
